commit.message:
Add an experimental backend that uses Lean to discharge goals (#850)

This experimental new backend translates passive Boogie programs into
Lean programs including theorems that can be automatically discharged by
the [`lean-auto`](https://github.com/leanprover-community/lean-auto)
package.

**Note:** The code is almost entirely separate from the existing Boogie
codebase, and modifies that code in only tiny ways (to provide an
additional command and invoke the new backend when it's enabled).
Because of this, and because of its current experimental nature, I'm
happy to do as little or as much code review on the new directory as
other folks want.

It has several goals:
* To allow axioms written in Boogie to be proven to have models and
therefore to be consistent.
* To allow pre-processing goals before sending them to SMT, possibly
discharging some without needing SMT.
* To allow experimentation with new tactics and decision procedures that
will more frequently discharge goals without the need for SMT.
* To allow the use of SMT proof certificates to increase assurance in
solver results (though this will require additions to `lean-auto`).
* Possibly: to allow interactive proofs of certain goals, which could
use infrastructure such as
[`mathlib4`](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4).

At the moment, completing proofs with the backend is manual. When given
the `/printLean:file.lean` option, it prints the Lean program to a file right
before the verification starts. It will probably need to stay this way until we
build some additional Lean infrastructure. Ultimately, however, the plan is
to make it as integrated and automatic as the current SMT-based
verification pipeline.

It includes a new test workflow with test files in `Test/lean-auto`.
This currently checks that it succeeds on several of the tests in
`Test/textbook` but will gradually expand to cover more of the test
suite.

verification.payload:
tree 109fe87c568624d3b82cfe891715b674af665878
parent 5c786ff9ddf907a069cc69f1830e0d670db09250
author Aaron Tomb <aarotomb@amazon.com> 1710888920 -0700
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1710888920 +0100

Add an experimental backend that uses Lean to discharge goals (#850)

This experimental new backend translates passive Boogie programs into
Lean programs including theorems that can be automatically discharged by
the [`lean-auto`](https://github.com/leanprover-community/lean-auto)
package.

**Note:** The code is almost entirely separate from the existing Boogie
codebase, and modifies that code in only tiny ways (to provide an
additional command and invoke the new backend when it's enabled).
Because of this, and because of its current experimental nature, I'm
happy to do as little or as much code review on the new directory as
other folks want.

It has several goals:
* To allow axioms written in Boogie to be proven to have models and
therefore to be consistent.
* To allow pre-processing goals before sending them to SMT, possibly
discharging some without needing SMT.
* To allow experimentation with new tactics and decision procedures that
will more frequently discharge goals without the need for SMT.
* To allow the use of SMT proof certificates to increase assurance in
solver results (though this will require additions to `lean-auto`).
* Possibly: to allow interactive proofs of certain goals, which could
use infrastructure such as
[`mathlib4`](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4).

At the moment, completing proofs with the backend is manual. When given
the `/printLean:file.lean` option, it prints the Lean program to a file right
before the verification starts. It will probably need to stay this way until we
build some additional Lean infrastructure. Ultimately, however, the plan is
to make it as integrated and automatic as the current SMT-based
verification pipeline.

It includes a new test workflow with test files in `Test/lean-auto`.
This currently checks that it succeeds on several of the tests in
`Test/textbook` but will gradually expand to cover more of the test
suite.

commit.message:
Fix crash on low rlimit (#859)

Z3 has multiple ways of responding that the resource limit has been
exceeded. In some cases it responds with an error message including
"push canceled". This updates Boogie to handle more of the strange side
cases.

verification.payload:
tree 7f4c84dce057fbb16a736db88e09f8271cd69b17
parent 6e9cce4dbaab7ae92080ceec3af261906f7b3429
author Aaron Tomb <aarotomb@amazon.com> 1710289000 -0700
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1710289000 -0700

Fix crash on low rlimit (#859)

Z3 has multiple ways of responding that the resource limit has been
exceeded. In some cases it responds with an error message including
"push canceled". This updates Boogie to handle more of the strange side
cases.

commit.message:
[Civl] Fix ChangRoberts (#858)

This PR provides a new proof for the Chang Roberts protocol for leader
election. The new proof is different from the existing Civl proof in two
ways:
- Stronger specification is proved. The new proof proves that a unique
leader will be elected in all terminal states. The old proof only proved
that conflicting leaders are not elected.
- The modeling of the protocol avoids the use of channels and achieves
all communication asynchronous calls.

---------

Co-authored-by: Shaz Qadeer <shaz@meta.com>

verification.payload:
tree 797c1a1859a35f1b3df4e8b850cdb9f7da177524
parent cf5609ff05e8168ff7a7362b8b3002961c72f704
author Shaz Qadeer <shaz.qadeer@gmail.com> 1709999395 -0800
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1709999395 -0800

[Civl] Fix ChangRoberts (#858)

This PR provides a new proof for the Chang Roberts protocol for leader
election. The new proof is different from the existing Civl proof in two
ways:
- Stronger specification is proved. The new proof proves that a unique
leader will be elected in all terminal states. The old proof only proved
that conflicting leaders are not elected.
- The modeling of the protocol avoids the use of channels and achieves
all communication asynchronous calls.

---------

Co-authored-by: Shaz Qadeer <shaz@meta.com>

commit.message:
Added quantifier instantiation option (#857)

Added option ```/keepQuantifier``` which allows the original quantifier
to be kept along with the instances. By default, the original quantifier
is dropped if any instances are found. More hints had to be added to a
few Civl benchmarks.

Co-authored-by: Shaz Qadeer <shaz@meta.com>

Added quantifier instantiation option (#857)

Added option ```/keepQuantifier``` which allows the original quantifier
to be kept along with the instances. By default, the original quantifier
is dropped if any instances are found. More hints had to be added to a
few Civl benchmarks.

commit.message:
Reset predecessors before focusing (#856)

There are two calls to `FocusAndSplit` in Boogie. Before one, there was
already a call to `ResetPredecessors`, but not before the other. Now
they both work on an implementation where the `Predecessors` attributes
has been reset.

---------

Co-authored-by: Remy Willems <rwillems@amazon.com>

verification.payload:
tree 2be624d08cf607958ef583decc380bf0ecc9b47d
parent 9b83c3afa95061d9575369127e81a349f2391363
author Aaron Tomb <aarotomb@amazon.com> 1709850002 -0800
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1709850002 +0000

Reset predecessors before focusing (#856)

There are two calls to `FocusAndSplit` in Boogie. Before one, there was
already a call to `ResetPredecessors`, but not before the other. Now
they both work on an implementation where the `Predecessors` attributes
has been reset.

---------

Co-authored-by: Remy Willems <rwillems@amazon.com>

commit.message:
[Civl] Fixed bug in refinement check for actions (#853)

The refinement check for actions was handling the frame condition
correctly. Now the frame condition is handled in the same manner as the
refinement check for procedures.

commit.message:
[Civl] New design of permissions (#851)

This PR implements a new design for the permission system in Civl. There
are two important changes:
- It is no longer possible to specify custom permission collectors.
Instead there is a fixed type-directed algorithm for collecting
permissions.
- String domain names are eliminated. Instead, each domain is identified
by a permission type, which is the type of each element of the
permission sets obtained via permission collection. Any type may be used
as a permission type.
 
Collection is orchestrated via three basic types---One, Set, Map. Types
embedded with a datatype are collected via a recursive traversal. The
primitives for permission transfer are designed afresh. Their signatures
can be seen in base.bpl. These primitives are the only mechanism for
permission redistribution apart from passing permissions to pending
asyncs. Therefore, for atomic actions that do not create pending asyncs,
the need for verifying the correctness of permission redistribution is
eliminated.

The bulk of the change in this PR is updating the regression tests to
account for the new method for specifying and collecting permissions.

In addition to the changes mentioned above:
- bug fixes in monomorphization and quantifier instantiation
- reorganization of tests into folders; new folders civl/paxos and
civl/large-samples; folded civl/podelski into civl/samples.

Outstanding issues:
- Paxos proof is flaky; current suspicion is that there might be a bug
in pool-based quantifier instantiation for lambdas
- Tests for the linear type checker are far from adequate

---------

Co-authored-by: Shaz Qadeer <shaz@meta.com>

verification.payload:
tree c35de0f6f587d9c7865b0724fa71f409b809703f
parent b782ca9ced30f0c3ba71aaae2e2fd1369c41626a
author Shaz Qadeer <shaz.qadeer@gmail.com> 1708411882 -0800
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1708411882 -0800

[Civl] New design of permissions (#851)

This PR implements a new design for the permission system in Civl. There
are two important changes:
- It is no longer possible to specify custom permission collectors.
Instead there is a fixed type-directed algorithm for collecting
permissions.
- String domain names are eliminated. Instead, each domain is identified
by a permission type, which is the type of each element of the
permission sets obtained via permission collection. Any type may be used
as a permission type.
 
Collection is orchestrated via three basic types---One, Set, Map. Types
embedded with a datatype are collected via a recursive traversal. The
primitives for permission transfer are designed afresh. Their signatures
can be seen in base.bpl. These primitives are the only mechanism for
permission redistribution apart from passing permissions to pending
asyncs. Therefore, for atomic actions that do not create pending asyncs,
the need for verifying the correctness of permission redistribution is
eliminated.

The bulk of the change in this PR is updating the regression tests to
account for the new method for specifying and collecting permissions.

In addition to the changes mentioned above:
- bug fixes in monomorphization and quantifier instantiation
- reorganization of tests into folders; new folders civl/paxos and
civl/large-samples; folded civl/podelski into civl/samples.

Outstanding issues:
- Paxos proof is flaky; current suspicion is that there might be a bug
in pool-based quantifier instantiation for lambdas
- Tests for the linear type checker are far from adequate

---------

Co-authored-by: Shaz Qadeer <shaz@meta.com>

commit.message:
Allow `/prune:0` to disable pruning (#848)

Add a `/noprune` flag to turn off pruning. It's off by default, but this
can be convenient if a) it's turned on earlier on the command line, or
b) Boogie is being used from another system like Dafny.

I would have made it `/prune:{1,0}`, but it's harder to make that
backward compatible with the current behavior.

verification.payload:
tree e9981505114651863af6c63bbb40841681c621ea
parent 83e8893af2eda384be8d28c40160babe5fdf7beb
author Aaron Tomb <aarotomb@amazon.com> 1707904308 -0800
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1707904308 +0100

Allow `/prune:0` to disable pruning (#848)

Add a `/noprune` flag to turn off pruning. It's off by default, but this
can be convenient if a) it's turned on earlier on the command line, or
b) Boogie is being used from another system like Dafny.

I would have made it `/prune:{1,0}`, but it's harder to make that
backward compatible with the current behavior.

commit.message:
Print resource counts when using -smoke (#845)

Previously, the output of `-trace` when using `-smoke` didn't indicate
the resource count for each attempt to prove `false`, only the time. Now
it prints both. This PR also disables pruning when `-smoke` is enabled,
because pruning currently leads to SMT syntax errors.

verification.payload:
tree e52f92664278f6e8e28e9d1bbec945002b6c9617
parent fbf1aa2c6bb2c09a26f03d582ccf1bd115476dad
author Aaron Tomb <aarotomb@amazon.com> 1707472340 -0800
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1707472340 +0100

Print resource counts when using -smoke (#845)

Previously, the output of `-trace` when using `-smoke` didn't indicate
the resource count for each attempt to prove `false`, only the time. Now
it prints both. This PR also disables pruning when `-smoke` is enabled,
because pruning currently leads to SMT syntax errors.

commit.message:
Verification task per split (#841)

Dependent Dafny PR: https://github.com/dafny-lang/dafny/pull/5031

### Changes
- Change the API `executionEngine.GetImplementationTasks` to
`executionEngine.GetVerificationTasks`, which returns a task for each
statically defined assertion batch. When using the split on every assert
option, this will return a verification task for each assertion.

### Testing
- Added test SplitOnEveryAssertion

---------

Co-authored-by: Aaron Tomb <aarotomb@amazon.com>

verification.payload:
tree 5377b787f33be0b81287c7b33e9ade4640c7b033

author Remy Willems <rwillems@amazon.com> 1706896450 +0100
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1706896450 +0100

Verification task per split (#841)

Dependent Dafny PR: https://github.com/dafny-lang/dafny/pull/5031

### Changes
- Change the API `executionEngine.GetImplementationTasks` to
`executionEngine.GetVerificationTasks`, which returns a task for each
statically defined assertion batch. When using the split on every assert
option, this will return a verification task for each assertion.

### Testing

commit.message:
Some refactoring in the VCGeneration assembly (#840)

### Changes
- Rename VCGen to VerificationConditionGenerator
- Rename VerificationResult to ImplementationRunResult
- Rename VCResult to VerificationRunResult
- Move several classes into separate files: BlockListComparer,
BlockStats, VerificationResultCollector
- Move several methods from Split into several new files:
BlockTransformation.cs, CommandTransformations.cs, ManualSplitFinder.cs
and FocusAttribute.cs
- Rename `ConditionGeneration.Outcome` to `VcOutcome` and move it to the
outer scope
- Move `ProverInterface.Outcome` to the outer scope

### Testing
This is pure almost fully automated refactoring, so this is covered by
existing automated tests

tree 228d33ef26ed3f91cd8553f5178d2a7e9f65832d

- Rename VerificationResult to ImplementationRunResult

- Move several classes into separate files: BlockListComparer,

- Move several methods from Split into several new files:

outer scope

existing automated tests

commit.message:
Use correct flag when checking if captureState assumptions need to be inserted (#835)

When discharging verification conditions, Boogie optionally inserts
`:captureState` assumptions into the AST. This improves error reporting
in case of a proof failure. Currently, these assumptions are only
inserted if the user wants to print the counterexample model to a file.
However, a counterexample model is sometimes used within Boogie without
being printed to a file, in which case the `:captureState` assumptions
should still be inserted. This PR changes the condition under which
Boogie adds `:captureState` assumptions to account for such scenarios.

verification.payload:
tree fa7d6b70b360d534c38ecaa2c5e6b5baec9248d7
parent 2f8cbdebe150ce04180290893907690ab964a03f
author Aleksandr Fedchin <sasha.fedchin@gmail.com> 1705661876 -0500
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1705661876 +0100

Use correct flag when checking if captureState assumptions need to be inserted (#835)

When discharging verification conditions, Boogie optionally inserts
`:captureState` assumptions into the AST. This improves error reporting
in case of a proof failure. Currently, these assumptions are only
inserted if the user wants to print the counterexample model to a file.
However, a counterexample model is sometimes used within Boogie without
being printed to a file, in which case the `:captureState` assumptions
should still be inserted. This PR changes the condition under which
Boogie adds `:captureState` assumptions to account for such scenarios.

commit.message:
[Civl] Fix primitives (#833)

This PR attempts to fix up the layer 0 primitives used in the Treiber
stack example so that they make more sense. There is considerable
improvement from before. One annoying thing still left is the presence
of ```assume``` statements in the definition of ```AtomicLoadNode#0```.
These ```assume``` statements are converted into ```assert``` statements
in the next layer up inside ```AtomicLoadNode```. But it would be better
to refactor the proof somehow to have the ```assert``` statements at the
lowest layer.

Co-authored-by: Shaz Qadeer <shaz@meta.com>

verification.payload:

author Shaz Qadeer <shaz.qadeer@gmail.com> 1705148569 -0800
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1705148569 -0800

commit.message:
[Civl] Gc cleanup (#832)

The main goal of this PR is to ensure that the state at the lowest layer
makes sense.
- mutatorsInRootScanBarrier is introduced
- allocSet is introduced
- linear thread ids of type Tid are introduced
- concrete boolean lock is abstracted to absLock

Additionally, silly names of various procedures were cleaned up to
become more consistent.

---------

[Civl] Gc cleanup (#832)

The main goal of this PR is to ensure that the state at the lowest layer
makes sense.
- mutatorsInRootScanBarrier is introduced
- allocSet is introduced
- linear thread ids of type Tid are introduced
- concrete boolean lock is abstracted to absLock

Additionally, silly names of various procedures were cleaned up to
become more consistent.

---------

Co-authored-by: Shaz Qadeer <shaz@meta.com>

commit.message:
[Civl] allow variable hiding in action refinement (#831)

This PR makes it possible to hide variables in an action refinement
step. The main motivation at the moment is to have the description of
```A_Paxos'``` refer only to ```decision```.

Co-authored-by: Shaz Qadeer <shaz@meta.com>

commit.message:
[Civl] Combine linear heaps and maps into a single abstraction (#830)

This PR unifies Lmap and Lheap into a single abstraction with the latter
being defined in terms of the former.
```
type Lheap T = Lmap (Ref T) T
```
The type ```Ref T``` is explained below.

The implementation of Lmap primitives is done by modeling them directly
as pure procedures in Boogie syntax. Thus a lot of rewriting code in
LinearRewriter.cs is eliminated. However, inlining of atomic actions had
to be adjusted to allow for calling and inlining pure procedures from
atomic actions. It is possible that these changes can be reverted by
modeling these primitives as pure actions (which are already callable
from both yield procedures and actions).

An important innovation is separating the Lmap primitives from the
dynamic allocation of keys for which two separate types are provided.

```
type Loc _;
datatype Ref<V> {
  Ref(loc: Loc V),
  Nil()
}
```
The type ```Loc``` models a dynamically-allocated location. The
allocation itself is performed by the ```Loc_New``` primitive:
```
pure procedure {:inline 1} Loc_New<V>() returns (k: Lval (Loc V)) { }
```
The caller gets a fresh location (notice the ```Lval``` wrapper) every
time ```Loc_New``` is called. An instance of ```Loc T``` may be wrapped
into an instance of ```Ref T``` via the ```Ref``` constructor.

Two separate types ```Loc``` and ```Ref``` are needed because we want
the domains of different ```Lheap T``` values to be disjoint. At the
same time, we want to provide the capability to have unique references
to locations. If we unified ```Loc``` and ```Ref```, then we cannot have
both capabilities.
